_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Branch Manager implements the Risk Management Plan (RMP), Risk Management Program, and Process Safety Management Program (PSM) for the temporary storage of anhydrousammonia in Railcar & Tanker Truck at this Facility, and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed.  The Risk Management Program includes an Accident Prevention Program/PSM that includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Mechanical Integrity, Pre-Startup Review, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, Employee Participation, Hot Work Permit, and Contractor requirements.

Helena receives anhydrous ammonia by railcar or tanker truck.  If by railcar, the railcar is temporarily parked on the Facilities rail spur in anticipation of the anhydrous ammonia being reacted by an Independent Fertilizer Contractor (See Fertilizer Reacting Process). It is anticipated that a single 34,000-gallon railcar would be delivered for reacting.  The Branch Manager implements the Risk Management Program while the railcar(s) is parked on the Facility property, at break times during the reacting process, and when the reaction process is complete and residual anhydrous ammonia may remain in the railcar. The Independent Fertilizer Contractor is responsible for the process at the time that reacting is occuring.  Helena personnel are trained to stay clear from this process during its operation.

If by tanker truck, the 8,500-gallon tanker truck is temporarily parked on the Facility property while the anhydrous ammonia is transferred to the on-site storage tank.  This transfer process is conducted by the tanker truck operator.  Helena does not own or operate the tanker truck.  The vendor is responsible to Helena for complying with relevant operation, maintenance, and training procedures and documentation.  At a minimum, the vendor must (1) have in place and certify compliance with applicable and relevant OSHA regulations, (2) make available to Helena and EPA upon request any contractor-related documentation necessary to comply with the RMP, and (3) certify that it has in place emergency shut-down procedures for ammonia unloading operations and that its OSHA programs comply with federal, state, and local regulatory requirements.  Further, Helena will provide a copy of its Contingency Plan to its vendor for review and a copy of its RMPr Document upon request.  Helena personnel are trained to stay clear from this process during its operation.

_prev_prog_3.Description: An Independent Fertilizer Reacting Contractor (IFRC) transfers the anhydrous ammonia from the 34,000-gallon railcar that is temporarily parked on the Facility property and reacts the anhydrous ammonia with phosphoric acid and water to produce ammonium phosphate fertilizer.  Helena does not own or operate the process.  The IFRC is responsible to Helena for complying with relevant operation, maintenance, and training procedures and documentation.  At a minimum, the IFRC must (1) have in place and certify compliance with OSHA Process Safety Management Plan (PSM), (2) make available to Helena and EPA upon request any documentation necessary to comply with the PSM and RMP, and (3) certify that it has in place emergency shut-down procedures for ammonia unloading and reactor operations and that its PSM support programs comply with federal, state, and local regulatory requirements.  The Helena Branch Manageris responsible for evaluating the IFRC past performance under the RMP program and for providing notification to the LEPC and Fire Department when itA?s IFRC intends to operate the reactor.  Further, Helena will provide a copy of its Contingency Plan to its contractors for review and implementation of emergency notifications procedures and a copy of its RMP Program Document upon request.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Helena Chemical Company (Helena) Madison Facility has submitted this updated electronic RMP in compliance with the provisions of the Clean Air Act 112 (r) as codified by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency at 40 CFR Part 68.  This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia from the Madison Facility located at 620 SW Third Street, Madison, SD 57042.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Madison Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Madison Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release (even though a release is unlikely) will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.

PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP

Helena has updated this RMP to include three different covered processes: (1) an on-site Tank Storage and Filling, (2) a temporary ammonia storage process (Railcar or Tanker Truck); and (3) a mobile fertilizer reacting process.  Future operation at the Facility may include the temporary storage of anhydrous ammonia in a railcar process and a fertilizer reacting process.  These processes will be managed in accordance with the requirements of a Program Level 3.  The on-site tank storage and filling process will be managed as a Program Level 2.  Helena is resubmitting this RMP as a 5-Year update.  As part of the update, Helena updated the off-site consequence analysis for the worst case and the alternative case release scenarios for each covered process.

FACILITY

The Madison Facility is a retail agricultural chemical facility.  Anhydrous ammonia is currently transported to the Facility via tanker truck and then transferred into the on-site 12,000-gallon storage tank.  The Vendor (i.e. tanker truck operator) is responsible to Helena for complying with relevant operation, maintenance, and training procedures and documentation.  

From the storage

tank, the anhydrous ammonia is transferred to nurse tanks and sold as retail to the end user.  The on-site tank storage and filling process is performed by qualified and trained Facility personnel.  Facility personnel conduct the storage and filling procedures in accordance with its Operating Procedures.  

Future operations may include two additional processes that include (1) transportation and temporary storage of anhydrous ammonia in a 34,000-gallon railcar, and (2) fertilizer reacting.  Anhydrous ammonia temporarily stored in the railcar will be reacted with phosphoric acid in a mobile pipe reactor and then diluted with water.  Helena does not own or operate the railcar or reacting process, but does operate the tank storage and filling process.  The reacting process and its ancillary unloading procedures (i.e. from a railcar) are performed by an Independent Fertilizer Reacting Contractor (IFRC).  After the reacting process is complete, any residual anhydrous ammonia is stored in the transportation containers until the transportation company removes the container from the Helena Facility.

OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst case and alternative case offsite consequence analyses were completed for each covered process (i.e. Tank Storage & Filling, Railcar and tanker Truck Storage, and Fertilizer Reacting).  The worst case scenario release for the Madison Facility assumes that all the contents of the largest single vessel (a single railcar or single storage tank) are released.  The release was modeled as if the railcar or storage tank was punctured on the side at the ground level. The resulting release of ammonia was modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.

The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario for the Railcar covered process assumes that a vapor valve is leaking or is not fully closed.  (The scenario actually assumes the valve is only 50% closed.)  The alternative scenario for the Reacting and Tank Storage covered processes are the same and assum

es that liquid transfer line up to 2-inches in diameter is severed during the reacting or filling process.  

ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Branch Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Helena facility.  The Branch Manager is assisted by other Helena staff, as directed.  The ammonia storage prevention program is implemented by Helena employees.  Helena employees inspect the markings on transportation containers (Railcar or Tanker Trucks) to ensure that the containers are operated within the U.S. DOT required inspection requirements and they inspect the Bill of Lading to ensure that the containers are not overfilled.  Helena employees also conduct inspections of railcars, tanker trucks, and its on-site storage tank for leaking valves and fittings in accordance with the accident program detailed in the Risk Management Program document.  

The reacting process prevention program is implemented by the IFRC because Helena does not own or operate the reacting process.  Helena requires the IFRC to certify its compliance with a Process Safety Management Plan and it spot checks some aspects of the contractorA?s PSM documentation (e.g. maintenance, training records) to ensure that the Contractor is complying with its PSM Plan.  

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

HelenaA?s Madison Facility is a non-responding facility. Helena has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department.  Helena has a written Contingency Plan that includes procedures to notify local emergency response agencies in event of a significant ammonia release.  Helena employees will not, under any circumstance, serve as first responders to a significant release of ammonia.

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at the Ma

dison Facility.

CONCLUSION

The Risk Management Plan implemented by Helena Chemical Company at the Madison Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The RMP will be updated as the Madison Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the Lake County LEPC.

NOTE: Sections 4, 5, and 6 of the standard RMP produced by EPAA?s RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Madison Facility.
